author: T'was an old username and I'll change it soon.

text:
If you view the list of highest recorded IQ scores you will see a large number of them simply living normal lives. I think the issue is more complex then is immediately apparent. I think the kind of person that seeks to take an IQ test will likely know already they have a relatively high IQ. The kind of person that seeks a high score will more often be a high achiever, thus eventually attain success. Most people with a normal level of motivation will have passing interest in their IQ. The score itself can also change over the course of your life. The most famous IQ scores for geniuses will be determined after they have achieved success. I wouldn't be surprised if many of them had an average score in the years leading up to their success.

I suppose that if you enforced an IQ test on everybody you would surprised to know just how many normal people have a 120+ rating. For me personally, I went through a stage where I was impressed with my higher then average IQ. But, in hindsight the test really means nothing. Your actions are what counts, not an engineered test that makes a vague estimate of human intellect. The test is an effective guide to determine learning disabilities for very low IQ scores, but for an average person outside of medical diagnosis your intellect is more complex then a singular number, and based on the context of what you do.﻿

author: Delaquasson Ho

text:
Forgotten Tech-Gamer They are worth more than what the market has to offer. A typical person who goes through all the education and works 50-60 hour work weeks (as Musk has stated he expects from those under him) certainly deserves more than they earn. Which is around $80k for an aerospace engineer. Thats not a problem with Musk or SpaceX, but rather a problem with how the market functions. The market is very short sighted. And often doesn't end up putting much investment in areas that don't matter at the moment, but will in the future. Prime example being the energy sector which has remained largely stagnant since the 80s. 

   If we go by how true value is determined (productivity, efficiency + labor time) we can make an educated guess and say a SpaceX engineer, or aerospace engineer in general deserves more than their market value. Market value of course being a measure of demand and scarcity in one moment of time. With the latter of the two (scarcity) being prone artificial inflation. 

You're attacking a position the other commenter never stated he/she held in the first place. And doing so incompetently at that. Not sure why the mini rant was necessary lol.﻿

According to one of his reviewers who read the book they stated "This book is actually a very fascinating read. As far as being motivational or educational, it's neither of those. However, it is a detailed look into the mind of a very interesting person; namely, Roy "Cap" Philipose.

The best way I can describe Mr. Philipose is a nonfictional combination of Holden Caulfield and Ignatius J. Reilly. The book is completely devoid of any organization or focus (although it is separated into chapters at apparently random intervals) and is written in a stream-of-consciousness narrative style. This is what makes the book so entertaining; the fact that you are allowed to look around inside Mr. Philipose's brain for awhile and see his thoughts as they are happening.

As for the content of the book, there is really nothing of substance to be found. It's clear that the author's understanding of finance, economics, and business is rudimentary at best."﻿

text:
As someone who's been called a prodigy, my tactic to not go insane is:
1. To not think about it, just focus on what you're good at and make that one specific thing better. You can get back to other things when you are wiser... and afford it.
2. Do not try to be sane, you'll naturally draw in and be drawn to people who either tolerate or like your presence. Don't fake it, just relax and take it easy.
Oh, and get a skill, any skill, then get a job, holy shit jobs are amazing, no more existential crisis, no more fortnightly financial crisis, no more fitness related depression crisis (removalist/truck driver). Fuck, I'm excited now because I can actually afford those big dream projects I could never afford before!﻿

author: Yam

text:
To be honest, when the names of pseudo geniuses and real geniuses are cited in the same context, I become terribly annoyed. Like Thomas Edison and Nicola Tesla or Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak...
"The main reason why most people who call themselves geniuses aren't is because there are a lot of average people in this world and it is common for many of these average people to have high regards of themselves"
Well, it changes from society to society. While individualism is culturally not supported in some societies, it is in some societies.Narcissism really is not very common in eastern countries as much as it is in USA. There's no many even in USA when applied to percentage data. Then, where does this high self-image come from? Perhaps, the crooked perception coming from ignorance? The more you know, the more you realise how much you don't know. Practically speaking, it is very likely for you to become humbler as you learn new things.
Him saying he's a genius clearly has some statistical effect.
(Also see : dunning kruger syndrome)﻿
author: Tanjut Zeytindalı

text:
Tanjut Zeytindalı ''To be honest, when the names of pseudo geniuses and real geniuses are sited in the same context, I become terribly annoyed'' Lol, what happened?
